title: R41839
content: The Dodd-Frank Act established the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) within the Federal Reserve System to oversee various consumer financial products and services. The CFPB has regulatory, supervisory, and enforcement authority over institutions offering services like mortgage lending, credit card lending, and debt collection. It also implements federal consumer laws such as the Truth in Lending Act. The CFPB was created to oversee consumer financial products and services, including mortgage lending and credit card lending. It enforces federal consumer laws like the Truth in Lending Act and will have its full powers in effect by July 21, 2011, once a Director is appointed. The CFPB was created to oversee consumer financial products and services, including mortgage lending and credit card lending. The President has not appointed a Director to head the Bureau yet. The CFP Act provides the Secretary with interim authority over the Bureau until a Director is appointed, with Section 1066 outlining the Secretary's powers. Subsection 1066(b) allows the Treasury Department to provide administrative services to support the Bureau before the designated transfer date. The CFP Act grants the Secretary interim authority over the Bureau until a Director is appointed. Section 1066 outlines the Secretary's powers, including providing administrative services such as human resources and technology support. The Secretary's authority under subsection 1066(a) is limited to performing the functions of the Bureau until a Director is confirmed by the Senate. The Secretary's authority under subsection 1066(a) is limited to performing the functions of the Bureau until a Director is appointed. The powers provided to the Bureau under subtitle F do not expire until a Director is appointed. Subtitle F transfers consumer financial protection functions from seven transferor agencies to the Bureau. The powers transferred to the Bureau under subtitle F include rulemaking authority over consumer financial laws previously held by various agencies like HUD, FRB, OCC, OTS, FDIC, and NCUA, as well as enforcement authority over larger depository institutions. The Bureau also gains the authority to coordinate certain activities previously conducted by the FTC. The CFPB has the authority to coordinate the transfer of personnel from other agencies, with identified personnel required to be transferred within 90 days. The Secretary can exercise all transferred authorities until a CFPB Director is appointed, including consumer compliance supervisory powers and the ability to issue rules for implementing consumer laws. The CFPB has enforcement powers over depository institutions and the authority to issue rules to implement consumer laws. The Bureau's newly established powers include enhanced supervisory powers over non-depository financial institutions, new rulemaking powers, and limited enforcement powers over smaller depository institutions. The CFPB has supervisory powers over smaller depository institutions and certain non-depository financial institutions, including payday loan providers, mortgage brokers, and student loan providers. The Bureau can conduct examinations and impose reporting requirements to ensure compliance with consumer financial laws. The CFPB has supervisory powers over non-depository financial institutions, ensuring compliance with consumer laws through examinations and reporting requirements. Section 1024 grants the Bureau authority to register and set standards for these institutions, similar to how banking regulators oversee depository institutions. Additionally, the CFPB has consumer compliance enforcement powers over non-depository financial institutions. The CFPB has rulemaking powers under subtitle C and section 1022 of subtitle B of the CFP Act. Section 1022 establishes the Bureau's authority to prescribe regulations, issue orders, and issue guidance to administer consumer financial laws. Subtitle C provides more specific rulemaking authority, including the power to declare acts or practices as unfair, deceptive, or abusive. The Bureau can also require disclosures and establish model forms. Enforcement and supervisory powers over smaller depository institutions are limited. The CFPB's enforcement and supervisory powers over smaller depository institutions are limited, leaving the Bureau in a back-up role to banking regulators. The Bureau can refer potential enforcement actions to regulators and participate in examinations on a sampling basis. It will have access to examination reports and can require institutions to submit reports directly. This limited authority will take effect on the designated transfer date. The Bureau's limited supervisory and enforcement authority over smaller depository institutions will take effect on the designated transfer date. The newly established powers are not considered "administrative services" and may not be exercised until a Bureau Director is appointed. The actions taken by the Bureau so far have been administrative in nature or in preparation for substantive authorities to be implemented later. No regulations have been prescribed, no binding enforcement actions taken, and no supervisory powers exercised over financial institutions. The Bureau has not taken any binding enforcement actions or exercised supervisory powers over financial institutions. Instead, it has engaged with various parties, collected information on consumer financial products and services, complaints, and conducted administrative and preparatory steps in line with its responsibilities as outlined in the CFP Act. After the designated transfer date, the Bureau will acquire consumer compliance supervisory and enforcement powers over larger depository institutions, as well as rulemaking authority under TILA, RESPA, and other consumer laws. The Secretary's interim Bureau powers may expand if a Director is not appointed, potentially leading to substantive actions impacting financial institutions in consumer markets. The FRB proposed regulations under its TILA authority to impose origination standards on certain mortgage lenders. The 474-page proposal was issued on April 19, 2011, open for comments until July 22, 2011. The authority to prescribe regulations under TILA will transfer to the Bureau on July 21, 2011. Final regulations imposing mortgage origination standards must be prescribed by the Bureau, not the FRB. The Secretary may also have the authority to issue these final regulations until a Bureau Director is appointed. The Secretary may have the authority to issue final regulations until a Bureau Director is appointed under the CFP Act. However, there may be ambiguity in the limits of the Secretary's authority, leading to potential legal challenges from parties affected by the regulations. The outcomes of such lawsuits are unpredictable due to various factors that could influence the claims.
